001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
009import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorfulBatch;
010import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.Palette;
011
012import java.util.Random;
013
014/**
015 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int}, packed {@code float}, and {@link Color} values in the IPT
016 * color space. IPT has more perceptually-uniform handling of hue than some other color spaces, like YCwCm, and even
017 * though the version here gives up the complex exponential adjustments to various components that the original IPT
018 * paper used, it still is pretty good at preserving perceptual lightness. In most regards, this is a more
019 * thoroughly-constructed color space than YCwCm, but YCwCm may still be useful because of how it maps to aesthetic
020 * components of color. See {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} for docs on the I, P, and T channels.
021 * <br>
022 * You may prefer the IPT_HQ color space, {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools}, if you want
023 * better lightness handling at the expense of a small amount of speed. The Oklab color space is related to IPT and
024 * IPT_HQ, {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools}, and is faster at some complex operations.
025 */
026public class ColorTools {
027        /**
028         * No need to instantiate.
029         */
030        private ColorTools(){
031        }
032        /**
033         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, I (intensity or lightness), P
034         * (protan, a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish), T (tritan, a chromatic component ranging from
035         * bluish to yellowish), and A (alpha or opacity). As long as you use a batch with {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderIPT}
036         * as its shader, colors passed with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be
037         * interpreted as IPT. Intensity should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only
038         * black), and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). Protan and tritan range from 0.0 to 1.0, with
039         * grayscale results when both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When
040         * protan is high and tritan is low, the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when
041         * tritan is high and protan is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are high it tends to be orange.
042         * When protan and tritan are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of
043         * the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
044         * <br>
045         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
046         * intensity, protan, and tritan, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original I,
047         * P, and T values if the original values were in the range that {@link #intensity(float)}, {@link #protan(float)},
048         * and {@link #tritan(float)} return.
049         *
050         * @param intens     0f to 1f, intensity or I component of IPT, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
051         * @param protan     0f to 1f, protan or P component of IPT, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
052         * @param tritan     0f to 1f, tritan or T component of IPT, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
053         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
054         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
055         */
056        public static float ipt(float intens, float protan, float tritan, float alpha) {
057                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (tritan * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
058                                | ((int) (protan * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intens * 255) & 0xFF));
059        }
060
061        /**
062         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
063         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
064         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
065         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
066         */
067        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
068        {
069                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
070                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
071                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
072                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
073                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
074                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
075                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
076                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
077        }
078
079        /**
080         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
081         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
082         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
083         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
084         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
085         */
086        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
087        {
088                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
089                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
090                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
091                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
092                final int r = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
093                final int g = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
094                final int b = Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
095                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
096        }
097        /**
098         * Writes an IPT-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)})
099         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
100         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
101         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
102         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
103         */
104        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
105        {
106                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
107                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
108                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
109                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
110                editing.r = (0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t);
111                editing.g = (1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t);
112                editing.b = (0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t);
113                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
114                return editing.clamp();
115        }
116
117        /**
118         * Writes an IPT-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)})
119         * into an IPT-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
120         * colors in IPT format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderIPT} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
121         * <br>
122         * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
123         * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code ipt}, unchanged from its color space
124         * @param ipt a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
125         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
126         */
127        public static Color toIPTColor(Color editing, final float ipt){
128                Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, ipt);
129                return editing;
130        }
131
132        /**
133         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
134         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
135         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
136         */
137        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
138                final float r = (rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
139                final float g = (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
140                final float b = (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
141                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
142                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
143                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
144                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
145                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
146        }
147
148        /**
149         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
150         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
151         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
152         */
153        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
154                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
155                final float r = (abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
156                final float g = (abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
157                final float b = (abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f;
158
159                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
160                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
161                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
162                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
163                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
164        }
165
166        /**
167         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
168         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
169         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
170         */
171        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
172                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
173                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * color.r + 0.576951f * color.g + 0.233221f * color.b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
174                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * color.r - 0.73741f * color.g + 0.0681367f * color.b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
175                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * color.r + 0.655205f * color.g - 0.941748f * color.b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
176                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
177        }
178
179        /**
180         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
181         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
182         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
183         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
184         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
185         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
186         */
187        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
188                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
189                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.189786f * r + 0.576951f * g + 0.233221f * b) * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
190                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.669665f * r - 0.73741f * g + 0.0681367f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
191                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.286498f * r + 0.655205f * g - 0.941748f * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
192                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
193        }
194
195        /**
196         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
197         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
198         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
199         */
200        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
201        {
202                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
203                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
204                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
205                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
206                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
207        }
208
209        /**
210         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
211         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
212         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
213         */
214        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
215        {
216                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
217                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
218                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
219                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
220                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
221        }
222
223        /**
224         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
225         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
226         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
227         */
228        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
229        {
230                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
231                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
232                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
233                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
234                return Math.min(Math.max((int) ((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t) * 256.0), 0), 255);
235        }
236
237        /**
238         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
239         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
240         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
241         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
242         */
243        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
244        {
245                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
246        }
247
248        /**
249         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
250         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
251         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
252         */
253        public static float red(final float encoded)
254        {
255                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
256                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
257                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
258                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
259                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
260        }
261
262        /**
263         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
264         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
265         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
266         */
267        public static float green(final float encoded)
268        {
269                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
270                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
271                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
272                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
273                return Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
274        }
275
276        /**
277         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
278         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
279         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
280         */
281        public static float blue(final float encoded)
282        {
283                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
284                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
285                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
286                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
287                return Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
288        }
289
290        /**
291         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
292         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
293         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
294         */
295        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
296        {
297                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
298        }
299
300        /**
301         * Gets a color as an IPT packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
302         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
303         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
304         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
305         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
306         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
307         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
308         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
309         *
310         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
311         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
312         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
313         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
314         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
315         */
316        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
317                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
318                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
319                } else {
320                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
321                }
322        }
323
324        /**
325         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
326         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
327         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
328         */
329        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
330                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
331                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
332                if(Math.abs(i - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
333                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
334                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
335                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
336                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
337                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
338                float x, y, w;
339                if(g < b) {
340                        x = b;
341                        y = g;
342                }
343                else {
344                        x = g;
345                        y = b;
346                }
347                if(r < x) {
348                        w = r;
349                }
350                else {
351                        w = x;
352                        x = r;
353                }
354                return x - Math.min(w, y);
355//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
356//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
357//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
358        }
359
360        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
361                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
362                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
363                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
364                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
365                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
366                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
367                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
368
369                float x, y, w;
370                if(g < b) {
371                        x = b;
372                        y = g;
373                }
374                else {
375                        x = g;
376                        y = b;
377                }
378                if(r < x) {
379                        w = r;
380                }
381                else {
382                        w = x;
383                        x = r;
384                }
385                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
386                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
387        }
388
389        /**
390         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
391         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
392         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
393         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
394         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
395         */
396        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
397                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
398                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
399                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
400                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
401                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
402                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
403                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
404                float x, y, z, w;
405                if(g < b) {
406                        x = b;
407                        y = g;
408                        z = -1f;
409                        w = 2f / 3f;
410                }
411                else {
412                        x = g;
413                        y = b;
414                        z = 0f;
415                        w = -1f / 3f;
416                }
417                if(r < x) {
418                        z = w;
419                        w = r;
420                }
421                else {
422                        w = x;
423                        x = r;
424                }
425                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
426                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
427        }
428
429        /**
430         * The "intensity" of the given packed float in IPT format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
431         * 1.0f . You can edit the intensity of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and
432         * {@link #darken(float, float)}.
433         *
434         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
435         * @return the intensity value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
436         */
437        public static float intensity(final float encoded)
438        {
439                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
440        }
441
442        /**
443         * The "protan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with tritan describes the
444         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If protan is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
445         * blue; if protan is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the protan of a color with
446         * {@link #protanUp(float, float)} and {@link #protanDown(float, float)}.
447         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
448         * @return the protan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
449         */
450        public static float protan(final float encoded)
451        {
452                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
453        }
454
455        /**
456         * The "tritan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with protan describes the
457         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If tritan is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
458         * blue or purple; if tritan is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
459         * the tritan of a color with {@link #tritanUp(float, float)} and {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}.
460         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
461         * @return the tritan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
462         */
463        public static float tritan(final float encoded)
464        {
465                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
466        }
467
468        /**
469         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
470         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not IPT! Takes
471         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
472         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
473         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
474         * result of {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
475         * This won't allocate any objects.
476         * <br>
477         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
478         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
479         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
480         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
481         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
482         *
483         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
484         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
485         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
486         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
487         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
488         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
489         */
490        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
491                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
492                final float i = Math.min(Math.max(light + (e & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
493                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
494                if (i <= 0.001f)
495                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
496                final float p = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
497                final float t = ((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
498                final float r = Math.min(Math.max((0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t), 0f), 1f);
499                final float g = Math.min(Math.max((1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t), 0f), 1f);
500                final float b = Math.min(Math.max((0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t), 0f), 1f);
501                float x, y, z, w;
502                if(g < b) {
503                        x = b;
504                        y = g;
505                        z = -1f;
506                        w = 2f / 3f;
507                }
508                else {
509                        x = g;
510                        y = b;
511                        z = 0f;
512                        w = -1f / 3f;
513                }
514                if(r < x) {
515                        z = w;
516                        w = r;
517                }
518                else {
519                        w = x;
520                        x = r;
521                }
522                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
523                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
524                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
525                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
526                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
527        }
528
529        /**
530         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
531         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
532         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
533         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
534         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
535         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
536         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
537         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
538         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
539         */
540        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
541                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
542                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
543        }
544
545        /**
546         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
547         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
548         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
549         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
550         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
551         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
552         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
553         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
554         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
555         */
556        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
557                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
558                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
559        }
560
561        /**
562         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
563         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
564         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
565         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
566         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
567         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
568         * @see #protanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
569         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
570         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
571         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
572         */
573        public static float protanUp(final float start, final float change) {
574                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
575                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
576        }
577
578        /**
579         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
580         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
581         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
582         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
583         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
584         * intensity of start as-is.
585         * @see #protanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
586         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
587         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
588         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
589         */
590        public static float protanDown(final float start, final float change) {
591                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
592                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
593        }
594
595        /**
596         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
597         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
598         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
599         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
600         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
601         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and intensity of start as-is.
602         * @see #tritanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
603         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
604         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
605         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
606         */
607        public static float tritanUp(final float start, final float change) {
608                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
609                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
610        }
611
612        /**
613         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
614         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
615         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
616         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
617         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
618         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
619         * @see #tritanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
620         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
621         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
622         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
623         */
624        public static float tritanDown(final float start, final float change) {
625                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
626                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
627        }
628
629        /**
630         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
631         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
632         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
633         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
634         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
635         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
636         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
637         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
638         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
639         */
640        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
641                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
642                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
643        }
644
645        /**
646         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
647         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
648         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
649         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
650         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
651         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
652         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
653         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
654         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
655         */
656        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
657                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
658                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
659        }
660
661        /**
662         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
663         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
664         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes protan and tritan; it leaves intensity and alpha
665         * alone, unlike {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes intensity.
666         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
667         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
668         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
669         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
670         */
671        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
672                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
673                return ipt((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
674                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
675                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
676                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
677        }
678
679        /**
680         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
681         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
682         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only protan and tritan, but higher values for
683         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
684         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change intensity somewhat). If the color stays
685         * in-gamut, then intensity won't change; alpha never changes.
686         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
687         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
688         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
689         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
690         */
691        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
692                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
693                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
694                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
695                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
696                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
697        }
698
699        /**
700         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast with,
701         * gets a packed float IPT color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
702         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
703         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
704         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
705         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
706         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
707         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
708         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
709         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
710         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
711         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
712         * @return a different IPT packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
713         */
714        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
715        {
716                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
717                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
718                                i = (bits & 0xff),
719                                p = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
720                                t = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
721                                ci = (contrastBits & 0xff),
722                                cp = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
723                                ct = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
724                if((p - cp) * (p - cp) + (t - ct) * (t - ct) >= 0x10000)
725                        return mainColor;
726                return ipt(ci < 128 ? i * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - i * (0.45f / 255f), p / 255f, t / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
727        }
728
729        /**
730         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast
731         * with, gets a packed float IPT color with I that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s I,
732         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
733         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
734         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
735         * <br>
736         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
737         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
738         * averages the original I of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
739         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
740         * @param contrastingColor a packed IPT float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
741         * @return a different packed IPT float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
742         */
743        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
744        {
745                final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
746                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
747        }
748
749        /**
750         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's I and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
751         * with the original I. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
752         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
753         * @param mainColor a packed IPT float color
754         * @return a different packed IPT float color, with its I channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
755         */
756        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
757                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
758                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
759        }
760
761        /**
762         * Makes the additive IPT color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
763         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
764         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
765         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
766         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
767         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
768         * @return an IPT float color between gray and {@code color}
769         */
770        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
771                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
772                                is = 0x80, ps = 0x80, ts = 0x80,
773                                ie = (e & 0xFF), pe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, te = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
774                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (is + fraction * (ie - is)) & 0xFF)
775                                | (((int) (ps + fraction * (pe - ps)) & 0xFF) << 8)
776                                | (((int) (ts + fraction * (te - ts)) & 0xFF) << 16)
777                                | (ae << 24));
778        }
779
780        /**
781         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
782         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
783         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
784         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
785         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the I, P, and T of the
786         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
787         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers P and T extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to 1,
788         * but only internally for measuring distance).
789         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
790         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
791         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
792         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
793         */
794        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
795                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
796                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
797                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
798                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
799                final float limit = variance * variance;
800                float dist, x, y, z;
801                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
802                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
803                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
804                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
805                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
806                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
807                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += i, y = (p + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (t + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
808                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
809                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
810                }
811                return color;
812        }
813
814        /**
815         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as IPT, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
816         * @param packed a packed float color as IPT
817         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
818         */
819        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
820        {
821                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
822                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
823                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
824                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
825                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
826                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
827                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
828                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
829                        return false;
830                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
831                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
832        }
833        /**
834         * Returns true if the given IPT values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
835         * @param i intensity channel, as a float from 0 to 1
836         * @param p protan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
837         * @param t tritan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
838         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
839         */
840        public static boolean inGamut(float i, float p, float t)
841        {
842                p = (p - 0.5f) * 2f;
843                t = (t - 0.5f) * 2f;
844                final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p + 0.324891f * t;
845                if(r < -0.006f || r > 1.003f) return false;
846                final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p + 0.220439f * t;
847                if(g < -0.006f || g > 1.003f)
848                        return false;
849                final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p - 0.809638f * t;
850                return (b >= -0.006f && b <= 1.003f);
851        }
852
853        /**
854         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
855         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
856         * @param packed a packed float color in IPT format; often this color is not in-gamut
857         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
858         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
859         */
860        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
861                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
862                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
863                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
864                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
865                float p2 = p, t2 = t;
866                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
867                        final float r = 0.999779f * i + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
868                        final float g = 1.000150f * i - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
869                        final float b = 0.999769f * i + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
870                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
871                                break;
872                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
873                        p2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, p, progress);
874                        t2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, t, progress);
875                }
876                return ipt(i, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
877        }
878
879        /**
880         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
881         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
882         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
883         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
884         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
885         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
886         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
887         */
888        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t) {
889                return limitToGamut(i, p, t, 1f);
890        }
891        /**
892         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
893         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
894         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
895         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
896         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
897         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
898         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
899         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
900         */
901        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t, float a) {
902                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i, 0f), 1f);
903                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max((p - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
904                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max((t - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
905                a = Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f);
906                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
907                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
908                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
909                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
910                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
911                                break;
912                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
913                        p2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, p, progress);
914                        t2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, t, progress);
915                }
916                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, a);
917        }
918
919        /**
920         * Given a packed float IPT color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by adding the
921         * corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
922         * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This
923         * clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
924         * @param encoded a packed float IPT color
925         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
926         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
927         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
928         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
929         * @return a packed float IPT color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
930         */
931        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha) {
932                return editIPT(encoded, addI, addP, addT, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
933        }
934        /**
935         * Given a packed float IPT color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by first
936         * multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter,
937         * before clamping. This means the intensity value is multiplied by {@code mulI}, then has {@code addI} added, and
938         * then is clamped to the normal range for intensity (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the
939         * given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay
940         * unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates protan and
941         * tritan in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a
942         * less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much
943         * more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back
944         * to RGBA.
945         * @param encoded a packed float IPT color
946         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
947         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
948         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
949         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
950         * @param mulI how much to multiply the intensity channel by; should be non-negative
951         * @param mulP how much to multiply the protan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
952         * @param mulT how much to multiply the tritan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
953         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
954         * @return a packed float IPT color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
955         */
956        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha,
957                                                                float mulI, float mulP, float mulT, float mulAlpha) {
958                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
959                float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
960                float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
961                float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
962                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
963
964                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i * mulI + addI, 0f), 1f);
965                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max(p * mulP + addP, -1f), 1f);
966                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max(t * mulT + addT, -1f), 1f);
967                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
968                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
969                        final float r = 0.999779f * i2 + 1.0709400f * p2 + 0.324891f * t2;
970                        final float g = 1.000150f * i2 - 0.3777440f * p2 + 0.220439f * t2;
971                        final float b = 0.999769f * i2 + 0.0629496f * p2 - 0.809638f * t2;
972                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
973                                break;
974                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
975                        p2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, p, progress);
976                        t2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, t, progress);
977                }
978                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
979        }
980
981        /**
982         * Converts from a packed float in HSI format to a packed float in IPT format.
983         * @param packed a packed float in HSI format
984         * @return a packed float in IPT format
985         */
986        public static float fromHSI(float packed){
987                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
988                final float h = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
989                final float s = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
990                final float i = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
991                final float y = TrigTools.cos_(h) * s, z = TrigTools.sin_(h) * s;
992                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
993                final float crScale = (i - 0.5f + (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
994                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
995                final float mgScale = (i + 0.5f - (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
996                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
997                final float ybScale = (i - 0.5f + (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
998                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
999                final float d = 4f * s * scale / (MathUtils.sin(3.14159f * i) + 0.000001f);
1000
1001                final float p = y * d;
1002                final float t = z * d;
1003                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1004                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF));
1005        }
1006
1007        /**
1008         * Converts from hue, saturation, intensity, and alpha components (each ranging from 0 to 1 inclusive) to a packed
1009         * float color in IPT format.
1010         * @param hue hue, from 0 to 1 inclusive; 0 is red, 0.25 is yellow, 0.75 is blue
1011         * @param saturation saturation from 0 (grayscale) to a limit between 0 and 1 depending on intensity (it can be 1 only when intensity is 0.5)
1012         * @param intensity intensity, or lightness, from 0 (black) to 1 (white)
1013         * @param alpha alpha transparency/opacity, from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque)
1014         * @return a packed float in IPT format
1015         */
1016        public static float fromHSI(float hue, float saturation, float intensity, float alpha){
1017                final float y = TrigTools.cos_(hue) * saturation, z = TrigTools.sin_(hue) * saturation;
1018                final float crMid = 0.3481738f * y + 0.104959644f * z;
1019                final float crScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(crMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16420607f / -crMid;
1020                final float mgMid = 0.122068435f * y + -0.070396f * z;
1021                final float mgScale = (intensity + 0.5f - (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mgMid) >>> 31)) * -0.16136102f / -mgMid;
1022                final float ybMid = 0.020876605f * y + -0.26078433f * z;
1023                final float ybScale = (intensity - 0.5f + (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(ybMid) >>> 31)) * 0.16155326f / -ybMid;
1024                final float scale = Math.max(crScale, Math.max(mgScale, ybScale));
1025                final float d = 4f * saturation * scale / (MathUtils.sin(3.14159f * intensity) + 0.000001f);
1026
1027                final float p = y * d;
1028                final float t = z * d;
1029                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int)(alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (t * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1030                                | ((int) (p * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intensity * 255) & 0xFF));
1031        }
1032
1033        /**
1034         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1035         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1036         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1037         */
1038        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1039                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
1040                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
1041                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
1042                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
1043                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
1044                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1045                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
1046                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
1047        }
1048        /**
1049         * Limited-use; like {@link #randomColor(Random)} but for cases where you already have three floats (r, g, and b)
1050         * distributed how you want. This can be somewhat useful if you are using a "subrandom" or "quasi-random" sequence,
1051         * like the Halton, Sobol, or R3 sequences, to get 3D points and map them to colors. It can also be useful if you
1052         * want to randomly generate the RGB channels yourself and track the values produced, as you would if you wanted to
1053         * avoid generating too many colors with high blue, for instance. This approximately maps the r, g, and b parameters
1054         * to distances on the RGB axes of a rectangular prism, which is stretched and rotated to form the IPT gamut.
1055         * @param r red value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1056         * @param g green value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1057         * @param b blue value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
1058         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
1059         */
1060        public static float subrandomColor(float r, float g, float b) {
1061                r = Math.min(Math.max(r, 0f), 0.999f);
1062                g = Math.min(Math.max(g, 0f), 0.999f);
1063                b = Math.min(Math.max(b, 0f), 0.999f);
1064                final float ir = 0.1882353f, pr = 0.83137256f - 0.5f, tr = 0.6431373f - 0.5f;
1065                final float ig = 0.5764706f, pg = 0.12941177f - 0.5f, tg = 0.827451f - 0.5f;
1066                final float ib = 0.23137255f, pb = 0.53333336f - 0.5f, tb = 0.02745098f - 0.5f;
1067                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
1068                                | ((int) ((tr * r + tg * g + tb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1069                                | ((int) ((pr * r + pg * g + pb * b) * 127.5f + 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
1070                                | ((int) ((ir * r + ig * g + ib * b) * 255f) & 0xFF));
1071        }
1072}
